lines.text: Enter BERTRAM, LAFEU, and PAROLLES

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: They say miracles are past and we have our philosophical persons, to make modern and familiar, things supernatural and causeless. Hence is it that we make trifles of terrors, ensconcing ourselves into seeming knowledge, when we should submit ourselves to an unknown fear.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Why, tis the rarest argument of wonder that hath shot out in our latter times.

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: And so tis.

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: To be relinquishd of the artists,

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: So I say.

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: Both of Galen and Paracelsus.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: So I say.

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: Of all the learned and authentic fellows,

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Right so I say.

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: That gave him out incurable,

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Why, there tis so say I too.

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: Not to be helped,

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Right as twere, a man assured of a

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: Uncertain life, and sure death.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Just, you say well so would I have said.

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: I may truly say, it is a novelty to the world.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: It is, indeed: if you will have it in showing, you shall read it inwhat do you call there

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: A showing of a heavenly effect in an earthly actor.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Thats it I would have said the very same.

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: Why, your dolphin is not lustier: fore me, I speak in respect

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Nay, tis strange, tis very strange, that is the brief and the tedious of it and hes of a most facinerious spirit that will not acknowledge it to be the

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: Very hand of heaven.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Ay, so I say.

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: In a most weak and debile minister, great power, great transcendence: which should, indeed, give us a further use to be made than alone the recovery of the king, as to be generally thankful.
pausing
pausing

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: I would have said it you say well. Here comes the king.
Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: Lustig, as the Dutchman says: Ill like a maid the better, whilst I have a tooth in my head: why, hes able to lead her a coranto.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Mort du vinaigre! is not this Helen

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: Fore God, I think so.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: Go, call before me all the lords in court. Sit, my preserver, by thy patients side And with this healthful hand, whose banishd sense Thou hast repeald, a second time receive The confirmation of my promised gift, Which but attends thy naming. Fair maid, send forth thine eye: this youthful parcel Of noble bachelors stand at my bestowing, Oer whom both sovereign power and fathers voice I have to use: thy frank election make Thou hast power to choose, and they none to forsake.
Enter three or four Lords

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: To each of you one fair and virtuous mistress Fall, when Love please! marry, to each, but one!

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: Ild give bay Curtal and his furniture, My mouth no more were broken than these boys, And writ as little beard.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: Peruse them well: Not one of those but had a noble father.

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: Gentlemen, Heaven hath through me restored the king to health.

lines.speaker: all
lines.text: We understand it, and thank heaven for you.

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: I am a simple maid, and therein wealthiest, That I protest I simply am a maid. Please it your majesty, I have done already: The blushes in my cheeks thus whisper me, We blush that thou shouldst choose but, be refused, Let the white death sit on thy cheek for ever Well neer come there again.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: Make choice and, see, Who shuns thy love shuns all his love in me.

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: Now, Dian, from thy altar do I fly, And to imperial Love, that god most high, Do my sighs stream. Sir, will you hear my suit

lines.speaker: first lord
lines.text: And grant it.

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: Thanks, sir all the rest is mute.

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: I had rather be in this choice than throw amesace for my life.

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: The honour, sir, that flames in your fair eyes, Before I speak, too threateningly replies: Love make your fortunes twenty times above Her that so wishes and her humble love!

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: No better, if you please.

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: My wish receive, Which great Love grant! and so, I take my leave.

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: Do all they deny her An they were sons of mine, Id have them whipped or I would send them to the Turk, to make eunuchs of.

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: Be not afraid that I your hand should take Ill never do you wrong for your own sake: Blessing upon your vows! and in your bed Find fairer fortune, if you ever wed!

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: These boys are boys of ice, theyll none have her: sure, they are bastards to the English the French neer got em.

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: You are too young, too happy, and too good, To make yourself a son out of my blood.

lines.speaker: fourth lord
lines.text: Fair one, I think not so.

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: Theres one grape yet I am sure thy father drunk wine: but if thou best not an ass, I am a youth of fourteen I have known thee already.

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: [To BERTRAM]  I dare not say I take you but I give Me and my service, ever whilst I live, Into your guiding power. This is the man.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: Why, then, young Bertram, take her shes thy wife.

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: My wife, my liege! I shall beseech your highness, In such a business give me leave to use The help of mine own eyes.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: Knowst thou not, Bertram, What she has done for me

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: Yes, my good lord But never hope to know why I should marry her.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: Thou knowst she has raised me from my sickly bed.

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: But follows it, my lord, to bring me down Must answer for your raising I know her well: She had her breeding at my fathers charge. A poor physicians daughter my wife! Disdain Rather corrupt me ever!

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: Tis only title thou disdainst in her, the which I can build up. Strange is it that our bloods, Of colour, weight, and heat, pourd all together, Would quite confound distinction, yet stand off In differences so mighty. If she be All that is virtuous, save what thou dislikest, A poor physicians daughter, thou dislikest Of virtue for the name: but do not so: From lowest place when virtuous things proceed, The place is dignified by the doers deed: Where great additions swells, and virtue none, It is a dropsied honour. Good alone Is good without a name. Vileness is so: The property by what it is should go, Not by the title. She is young, wise, fair In these to nature shes immediate heir, And these breed honour: that is honours scorn, Which challenges itself as honours born And is not like the sire: honours thrive, When rather from our acts we them derive Than our foregoers: the mere words a slave Deboshd on every tomb, on every grave A lying trophy, and as oft is dumb Where dust and damnd oblivion is the tomb Of honourd bones indeed. What should be said If thou canst like this creature as a maid, I can create the rest: virtue and she Is her own dower honour and wealth from me.

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: I cannot love her, nor will strive to dot.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: Thou wrongst thyself, if thou shouldst strive to choose.

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: That you are well restored, my lord, Im glad: Let the rest go.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: My honours at the stake which to defeat, I must produce my power. Here, take her hand, Proud scornful boy, unworthy this good gift That dost in vile misprision shackle up My love and her desert that canst not dream, We, poising us in her defective scale, Shall weigh thee to the beam that wilt not know, It is in us to plant thine honour where We please to have it grow. Cheque thy contempt: Obey our will, which travails in thy good: Believe not thy disdain, but presently Do thine own fortunes that obedient right Which both thy duty owes and our power claims Or I will throw thee from my care for ever Into the staggers and the careless lapse Of youth and ignorance both my revenge and hate Loosing upon thee, in the name of justice, Without all terms of pity. Speak thine answer.

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: Pardon, my gracious lord for I submit My fancy to your eyes: when I consider What great creation and what dole of honour Flies where you bid it, I find that she, which late Was in my nobler thoughts most base, is now The praised of the king who, so ennobled, Is as twere born so.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: Take her by the hand, And tell her she is thine: to whom I promise A counterpoise, if not to thy estate A balance more replete.

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: I take her hand.

lines.speaker: king
lines.text: Good fortune and the favour of the king Smile upon this contract whose ceremony Shall seem expedient on the nowborn brief, And be performd tonight: the solemn feast Shall more attend upon the coming space, Expecting absent friends. As thou lovest her, Thy loves to me religious else, does err.
Exeunt all but LAFEU and PAROLLES

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: [Advancing]  Do you hear, monsieur a word with you.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Your pleasure, sir

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: Your lord and master did well to make his recantation.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Recantation! My lord! my master!

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: Ay is it not a language I speak

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: A most harsh one, and not to be understood without bloody succeeding. My master!

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: Are you companion to the Count Rousillon

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: To any count, to all counts, to what is man.

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: To what is counts man: counts master is of another style.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: You are too old, sir let it satisfy you, you are too old.

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: I must tell thee, sirrah, I write man to which title age cannot bring thee.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: What I dare too well do, I dare not do.

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: I did think thee, for two ordinaries, to be a pretty wise fellow thou didst make tolerable vent of thy travel it might pass: yet the scarfs and the bannerets about thee did manifoldly dissuade me from believing thee a vessel of too great a burthen. I have now found thee when I lose thee again, I care not: yet art thou good for nothing but taking up and that thout scarce worth.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Hadst thou not the privilege of antiquity upon thee,

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: Do not plunge thyself too far in anger, lest thou hasten thy trial which ifLord have mercy on thee for a hen! So, my good window of lattice, fare thee well: thy casement I need not open, for I look through thee. Give me thy hand.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: My lord, you give me most egregious indignity.

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: Ay, with all my heart and thou art worthy of it.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: I have not, my lord, deserved it.

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: Yes, good faith, every dram of it and I will not bate thee a scruple.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Well, I shall be wiser.

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: Even as soon as thou canst, for thou hast to pull at a smack o the contrary. If ever thou best bound in thy scarf and beaten, thou shalt find what it is to be proud of thy bondage. I have a desire to hold my acquaintance with thee, or rather my knowledge, that I may say in the default, he is a man I know.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: My lord, you do me most insupportable vexation.

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: I would it were hellpains for thy sake, and my poor doing eternal: for doing I am past: as I will by thee, in what motion age will give me leave.
Exit

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Well, thou hast a son shall take this disgrace off me scurvy, old, filthy, scurvy lord! Well, I must be patient there is no fettering of authority. Ill beat him, by my life, if I can meet him with any convenience, an he were double and double a lord. Ill have no more pity of his age than I would ofIll beat him, an if I could but meet him again.
Reenter LAFEU

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: Sirrah, your lord and masters married theres news for you: you have a new mistress.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: I most unfeignedly beseech your lordship to make some reservation of your wrongs: he is my good lord: whom I serve above is my master.

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: Who God

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Ay, sir.

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: The devil it is thats thy master. Why dost thou garter up thy arms o this fashion dost make hose of sleeves do other servants so Thou wert best set thy lower part where thy nose stands. By mine honour, if I were but two hours younger, Ild beat thee: methinks, thou art a general offence, and every man should beat thee: I think thou wast created for men to breathe themselves upon thee.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: This is hard and undeserved measure, my lord.

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: Go to, sir you were beaten in Italy for picking a kernel out of a pomegranate you are a vagabond and no true traveller: you are more saucy with lords and honourable personages than the commission of your birth and virtue gives you heraldry. You are not worth another word, else Ild call you knave. I leave you.
Exit

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Good, very good it is so then: good, very good let it be concealed awhile.
Reenter BERTRAM

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: Undone, and forfeited to cares for ever!

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Whats the matter, sweetheart

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: Although before the solemn priest I have sworn, I will not bed her.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: What, what, sweetheart

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: O my Parolles, they have married me! Ill to the Tuscan wars, and never bed her.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: France is a doghole, and it no more merits The tread of a mans foot: to the wars!

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: Theres letters from my mother: what the import is, I know not yet.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Ay, that would be known. To the wars, my boy, to the wars! He wears his honour in a box unseen, That hugs his kickywicky here at home, Spending his manly marrow in her arms, Which should sustain the bound and high curvet Of Marss fiery steed. To other regions France is a stable we that dwell int jades Therefore, to the war!

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: It shall be so: Ill send her to my house, Acquaint my mother with my hate to her, And wherefore I am fled write to the king That which I durst not speak his present gift Shall furnish me to those Italian fields, Where noble fellows strike: war is no strife To the dark house and the detested wife.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Will this capriccio hold in thee art sure

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: Go with me to my chamber, and advise me. Ill send her straight away: tomorrow Ill to the wars, she to her single sorrow.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Why, these balls bound theres noise in it. Tis hard: A young man married is a man thats marrd: Therefore away, and leave her bravely go: The king has done you wrong: but, hush, tis so.
Exeunt
